'''Wall Street West''' is a name used by [[Real estate development|real estate developers]], [[City manager|city officials]] and [[news media]] in the United States<ref>{{cite news|last=Hampson|first=Rick|title=Model of urban future: Jersey City?|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/nation/2007-04-15-jersey-city_N.htm|accessdate=10 March 2013|newspaper=USA Today|date=16 April 2007}}</ref> to call particular streets or places west of [[Manhattan]] that have a high concentration of [[Wall Street]] companies or a major [[Trade|exchange]]. The most notable for that is along the waterfront of [[Jersey City, New Jersey]].<ref name=businessweek>{{cite news|title=Jersey City: "Wall Street West"|url=http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2001-10-28/jersey-city-wall-street-west|accessdate=10 March 2013|newspaper=Bloomberg Business Week Magazine|date=28 October 2001}}</ref>
For those locations in the [[Western United States]], the name "'''Wall Street of the West'''" has been used in the latter part of the 19th century. [[Montgomery Street]] in [[San Francisco]] has been known by that nickname to date.<ref name=1906-san-francisco>{{cite book|last=Prentice|first=Carol S.|title=1906 San Francisco Earthquake Centennial Field Guides: Field Trips Associated With the 100th Anniversary Conference, 18-23 April 2006, San Francisco, California|date=28 February 2006|publisher=Geological Society of America|isbn=9780813700076|page=17|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CwchZE54dWYC&|accessdate=10 March 2013}}</ref> A couple of other places were known by that name for a period of time and that was faded away when the industry moved out to other areas.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Cecil|title=TV Taking Stock of 1929 Crash|accessdate=10 March 2013|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=22 Jul 1980|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/665093492.html?dids=665093492:665093492&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Jul+22%2C+1980&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=TV+TAKING+STOCK+OF+1929+CRASH&pqatl=google|page=G1}}</ref>
==Wall Street of the West== [[Image:Montgomerystreetsf.jpg|thumbnail|200px|Montgomery Street in San Francisco's financial district.]] The Montgomery Street in San Francisco started its transformation from the street with wood shacks, warehouses and retail stores in the 1850s. By the 1870s, more notable buildings were constructed to replace the old wood shacks and the [[mudflat|mud flats]].<ref name=1906-san-francisco/> The street continued to develop from that point with financial services companies located in that area. The Montgomery Street has been known as "Wall Street of the West" to date. The [[Financial District, San Francisco|Financial District]] has been expanded to cover the triangular area east of Grant Avenue, south of Washington Street, west of the [[Embarcadero (San Francisco)|Embarcadero]]. In 2012, when the [[Occupy movement]] had a protest at the [[Financial District, San Francisco|San Francisco's Financial District]] as a continuation of [[Occupy San Francisco]], the protesters went through the financial district under the banner ''Occupy Wall Street West''<ref>{{cite news|title=Occupy Wall Street West: New Movement Rises In San Francisco|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/01/18/occupy-wall-street-west_n_1214407.html|accessdate=9 March 2013|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=18 January 2012}}</ref> giving the shorter name of the financial district than its typical name as Wall Street of the West.
For [[Denver]], Colorado, the city started picking up some shares of commercial buildings in the late 19th century. There was a push by the local politicians to transform its Seventeenth Street to become the "Wall Street of the Denver" as seen in an 1892 pamphlet in promoting the [[Equitable Building (Denver, Colorado)|Equitable Building]] by the [[AXA Equitable Life Insurance Company|Equitable Life Assurance Society]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Spirits and Scandals on 17th and Stout Streets|url=http://coloradowest.auraria.edu/content/equitable-building|publisher=Center of the Colorado & the West at Auraria Library|accessdate=20 May 2013}}</ref> Other buildings were constructed at other corners of the 17th Street such as the [[Boston Building]] in 1890 and the Ideal Cement Building in 1907.<ref>{{cite web|title=Wall Street of the Rockies|url=http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=4659|publisher=HMdb.org The Historical Marker Database|accessdate=20 May 2013}}</ref> By that time, the 17th Street had been referred as "Wall Street of the West".<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gentry|first=Garland|title=Denver's Famous Street Lighting|journal=Public Service|date=July 1908|volume=V|issue=1|page=4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aBApAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> After the Colorado National Bank (First National Bank) was constructed in 1911, it reaffirmed its central business district's Wall Street status. The 17th Street was also called "Wall Street of the Rockies" at a later time as it attracted other premier financial institutions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Historic Resources of Downtown Denver|url=http://www.historycolorado.org/sites/default/files/files/OAHP/crforms_edumat/pdfs/646.pdf|work=National Register of Historic Places|publisher=United States Department of the Interior National Park Service|accessdate=20 May 2013}}</ref>
[[Los Angeles]] also picked up a fair share of financial companies starting in the early part of the 1900s. The new financial buildings were concentrating along South Spring Street. The title of "Wall Street of the West" was used and the [[Spring Street Financial District]] was born. The district continued to flourish for many decades until the 1960s when companies started shifting toward the western part of the downtown area.<ref>{{cite web|author=Tim Sitton (Los Angeles County Museum of Natural History)|title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory - Nomination Form: Spring Street Financial District, at page 8|publisher=Los Angeles Conservancy web site|date=July 1977|url=http://www.laconservancy.org/initiatives/Spring%20St%20Nomination%20PDF.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> By the early 1980s, many buildings were empty and the Spring Street showed no sign of its past as one of the financial centers.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rafter|first=Michelle|title=Spring Hopes Eternal|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997/nov/05/business/fi-50374/2|accessdate=10 March 2013|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=5 November 1997}}</ref>
[[Fort Worth, Texas]] was known as the "Wall Street of the West" starting in the early 1900s similarly to Los Angeles's South Spring Street. However, it was not the financial companies that gave [[Fort Worth Stockyards]] its Wall Street name, but the [[livestock]] trading. In 1902, the Livestock Exchange Building was constructed to house many livestock commission companies, [[Telegraphy|telegraph]] offices, railroad offices and other support businesses. The business grew to the peak at 1944 which processed 5,277,496 head of livestock. After that year, the livestock exchange business started to decline until its low point in 1986. The Livestock Exchange Building is now a historical site.<ref>{{cite web|title=A History of the Fort Worth Stockyards|url=http://www.stockyardsmuseum.org/index_files/StockYardsHistory.htm|publisher=stockyards Museum|accessdate=10 March 2013}}</ref>
==Jersey City== [[Image:Jersey City.JPG|thumb|250px|left|Southern part of the Wall Street West in Jersey City]] In the 1980s, some financial companies started moving from [[Manhattan]] to the west of the [[Hudson River]] to settle in the waterfront area of [[Jersey City, New Jersey]]. The area earned the name of "Wall Street West" after [[Bankers Trust]] had a major relocation to Jersey City in 1985. Other major financial firms followed shortly after with [[National Westminster Bank|National Westminster Bank of London]] building its domestic subsidiary there. [[Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette]] (DLJ) moved into a new 20-story building in the [[Exchange Place (Jersey City)|Exchange Place area]]. The new [[Harborside Financial Center]] were built with anticipation of more relocations. [[Daiwa Securities Group|Daiwa Securities]], [[Royal Bank of Canada]], and [[Chase Manhattan Bank]] were planning to have their major workforce there.<ref>{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Winston|title=On the Jersey City Docks, Wall St. West|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/10/28/nyregion/on-the-jersey-city-docks-wall-st-west.html|accessdate=20 May 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=28 October 1988}}</ref>
Another major development in Exchange Place started with a plan to redevelop the 34-acre former [[Colgate-Palmolive]] soap factory in 1988. The first building was [[101 Hudson Street]] with more than 3,000 [[Back office|back-office]] workers of [[Merrill Lynch]] and [[Lehman Brothers]] moved in by 1993.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lyons|first=Richard D.|title=Real Estate; Jersey City Project on Colgate Site|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/06/15/business/real-estate-jersey-city-project-on-colgate-site.html|accessdate=20 May 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=15 June 1988}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Deutsch|first=Claudia H.|title=Lehman Bros. to Move 900 Back-Office Jobs to Jersey City|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/10/14/nyregion/lehman-bros-to-move-900-back-office-jobs-to-jersey-city.html|accessdate=20 May 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=14 October 1993}}</ref>
On the northern side of Jersey City's waterfront, another major development called [[Newport, Jersey City|Newport]] was started in the late 1980s. It was planned as a mixed-use community with office, residential and retail buildings.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hevesi|first=Dennis|title=On the Hudson, a City Within Jersey City|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/13/realestate/on-the-hudson-a-city-within-jersey-city.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|accessdate=20 May 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=13 September 1998}}</ref> By early 2001, Newport had gained major tenants including [[UBS]], [[Knight Capital]], and [[Insurance Services Office]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Herman|first=Eric|title=UBS Nears Jersey City Office Lease|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/money/ubs-nears-jersey-city-office-lease-article-1.910855|accessdate=21 May 2013|newspaper=NY Daily News|date=13 January 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Knight/Trimark Group Signs Lease for New World Headquarters at Newport|url=http://www.knight.com/investorRelations/pressReleases.asp?compid=105070&releaseID=93436|accessdate=21 May 2013|newspaper=Knight Press Release|date=17 May 2000}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Construction of ISO Commercial Tower/Newport IV Building Ahead of Schedule|url=http://listings.cushwake.com/us/cw/News/media.cfm?artcl_id=666|accessdate=21 May 2013|newspaper=Cushman Wakefield Press Release|date=22 February 2000}}.</ref> By that time, the "Wall Street West" expanded to include the entire waterfront area from Newport to Exchange Place.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cadenilla|first=William|title=The Sixth Borough|url=http://www.jerseycityonline.com/jcedc/sixth_borough.htm|publisher=Jersey City Economic Development Corporation|accessdate=21 May 2013|year=2002}}</ref>
After the [[September 11 attacks]], there were renewed interests from financial firms to diversify their workforce to be outside of Manhattan. At the same time, there were immediate needs to find office space for misplaced workers who used to work in the [[Lower Manhattan]] area. Office space in Jersey City's waterfront became boom again due to its proximity to Lower Manhattan and the ferry services which were not affected by the attacks.<ref name=marketwatch>{{cite news|last=Gelsi|first=Steve|title=Wall Street moves west|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/wall-street-builds-waterfront-presence-in-jersey-city|accessdate=21 May 2013|newspaper=Market Watch|date=9 February 2002}}</ref> By the end of September 2001, ten of the largest 18 firms from the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] area including [[American Express]] and [[Deutsche Bank]] moved some of their operations to Jersey City.<ref name=businessweek/> [[Goldman Sachs]] at the time were planning to move its headquarters to the new building being constructed in Jersey City.<ref name=marketwatch/>
The boom since 2001 had been short live. By 2007, the vacancy rate had increased and some financial firms had scaled down their plans. UBS changed their plan not to fully occupy the newly constructed building. Goldman Sachs only partially occupied its building and planned to build a new headquarters in New York.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kornreich|first=Leron|title=therealdeal.com/issues_articles/nj-waterfront-vacancies-remain-high/|url=http://therealdeal.com/issues_articles/nj-waterfront-vacancies-remain-high/|accessdate=21 May 2013|newspaper=The Real Deal|date=17 October 2007}}</ref> The Wall Street West suffered further by the [[Financial crisis of 2007–08|2008 financial crisis]]. The office space vacancy rate spiked up as investment bank tenants started collapsing.<ref>{{cite news|title=New Jersey's `Wall Street West' Quakes Amid Namesake's Turmoil|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=ajRX_QI2ODtw&refer=home|accessdate=21 May 2013|newspaper=Bloomberg|date=17 September 2008}}</ref> The downturn economy had dampen the real estate growth in this area for many years.
As the economy started to slowly recover between 2011 and 2012, large leases started to pick up again especially in the Newport area with major financial institutions such as [[Citigroup]] and [[Fidelity Investments]]. [[Depository Trust and Clearing Corporation]] also moved the majority of its workforce from Manhattan to Jersey City.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hughes|first=C. J.|title=In Jersey City, a LeFrak Office Project Awaits a Tenant|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/18/realestate/commercial/lefrak-office-project-in-jersey-city-awaits-a-tenant.html?_r=0|accessdate=23 May 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=17 April 2012}}</ref>
Currently, the "Wall Street West" employment contributes to one third of the [[private sector]] jobs in Jersey City. Within the Financial Service cluster, there are three major sectors: more than 60 percent are in the [[Security (finance)|securities industry]]; 20 percent are in [[bank]]ing; and 8 percent in [[insurance]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Your Gateway to Opportunity, Enterprise Zone Five Year Strategic Plan 2010|url=http://www.jcedc.org/Pages/JerseyCity%20UEZ_Economics.pdf|publisher=Jersey City Economic Development Corporation|accessdate=23 May 2013}}</ref>
==Northeastern Pennsylvania== {{See also|Wall Street West (organization)}}
After the September 11 attacks, the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]], the [[Federal Reserve]] and the [[Office of the Comptroller of the Currency]] recommended that the data backup facilities of Wall Street firms should be moved away from New York City with a different [[power grid]], transportation network and [[Drainage basin|watershed]] than New York. In 2006, Governor of Pennsylvania, [[Ed Rendell]], announced the creation of "Wall Street West" initiative to attract 20 potential Wall Street firms to move their backup facilities to [[Northeastern Pennsylvania]] in nine counties:Northampton, Berks, Monroe, Carbon, Pike, Wayne, Luzerne and Lackawanna. He also pledged to invest in office space construction, infrastructure improvement and installation of [[fiber optic]] from New York City to the region. The region was chosen as it was still within the {{convert|125|mi}} from Manhattan which was considered far enough to sustain major disaster but still within the range of instantaneous data transmission via fiber optic. The first project was Penn Regional Business Center in Monroe County.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rubinkam|first=Michael|title=Pa. Wants to Become 'Wall Street West'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/10/08/AR2006100800378.html|accessdate=27 May 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=8 October 2006}}</ref>
At the beginning of the initiative, Ben Franklin Technology Partners of Northeast Pennsylvania (BFTP/NEP), a state-funded economic development network, worked closely with the Pennsylvania Department of [[Pennsylvania Department of Labor and Industry|Labor and Industry]] and [[Pennsylvania Department of Community and Economic Development|Community and Economic Development]] to develop a proposal for the federal grants through [[Workforce Innovation in Regional Economic Development]] (WIRED). The management was later turned to an independent unit called [[Wall Street West (organization)|Wall Street West]] with a 17-member Executive Committee.<ref>{{cite web|title=Early Implementation of Generation I WIRED Initiative 2007 Site Visit Highlights Wall Street West WIRED|url=http://wdr.doleta.gov/research/FullText_Documents/Appendix%20A%205-21-08.pdf|publisher=Berkeley Policy Associates|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref>
In June 2007, the initiative received an $8 million commitment from [[Level 3 Communications]] for a $40 million project to build a new fiber optic network from Manhattan to [[East Stroudsburg, Pennsylvania|East Stroudsburg]] with a branched-off network in [[Warren County, New Jersey|Warren County]] in New Jersey. This was to address the shortcoming of direct high-speed communication which was required by Wall Street firms.<ref>{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Rich|title=Wall Street West Gets Level 3 Link|url=http://www.datacenterknowledge.com/archives/2007/06/13/wall-street-west-gets-level-3-link/|accessdate=27 May 2013|newspaper=Data Center Knowledge|date=13 June 2007}}</ref> However, by June 2008, the initiative was unable to attract any Wall Street firm to the region with an exception of one financial services related company. A company which hosted compliance solutions for financial services opened its new data center in the region with 10 job creation. By that time, Level 3 Communications indicated that it would not build the fiber optic link unless more financial services firms commit to locate in the region and buy services from them. Part of the difficulties in attracting more companies was that many financial institutions were more comfortable with the shorter range of {{convert|70|km}} from Manhattan which caused many financial firms to build out their new data centers in [[Central Jersey]] instead.<ref>{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Rich|title=Why Wall Street West Has Struggled|url=http://www.datacenterknowledge.com/archives/2008/05/26/why-wall-street-west-has-struggled/|accessdate=27 May 2013|newspaper=Data Center Knowledge|date=26 May 2008}}</ref>
Without a commitment from financial services companies, the decision was made in 2009 to expand the Wall Street West mission to include healthcare, [[Materials science|advanced materials]] and diversified manufacturing, and [[logistics]] and transportation industries.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bringing Energy to Economic Development - Annual Report 2009|url=http://nep.benfranklin.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/01/BFTP-NEP_2009_annual_report.pdf|publisher=Ben Franklin Technology Partners of Northeastern Pennsylvania|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref>

{{small | (Senior Vice President, Chief Financial Officer)}} | industry = [[Waste management]] | fate = Sold to GFL Environmental | num_employees = 1600 | website = [http://www.WasteIndustries.com/ WasteIndustries.com] | intl = }} '''Waste Industries''' is a provider of non-hazardous [[solid waste]] and [[recycling]] collection, transfer, and disposal company in the southeast United States. The company has over 1.9 million service points. The company is dedicated to creating a better world through its Full Circle Project. In 2007, Waste Industries also began the process of reducing its number of [[diesel fuel|diesel]] trucks with compressed natural gas powered trucks. On October 10, 2018, the company announced its intentions to merge with a Canadian company for an undisclosed amount. The company will continue to operate as Waste Industries in the US and will be headquartered in Raleigh, North Carolina.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsobserver.com/news/business/article219777470.html?#emlnl=Breaking_Newsletter&id=c25vd2Nvb2w3NzZAZ21haWwuY29t|title=Raleigh’s Waste Industries merging with Canadian company|work=newsobserver|access-date=2018-10-10|language=en}} ==Company history== Waste Industries was created as a waste disposal firm in 1970 by [[Lonnie Poole Jr.]] who used funds from the sale of his Ohio home and borrowed money from Gregory Poole, Owner of a local construction company, to create the company. The initial idea of Waste Industries stemmed from market research Poole conducted, while concepting a new mobile [[landfill]] [[compactor]] while he was living in Ohio. His compactor idea failed, but Poole soon discovered his calling, and started Waste Industries in [[Raleigh, North Carolina]].[http://northcarolinahistory.org/encyclopedia/waste-industries-usa-inc/ North Carolina History Project] After a few years, of stagnation, the company grew in the 1970s and quickly expanded past Wake county and the city of Raleigh. By 1980 the company had reached ten million dollars in revenue and soon after, they named their first employee, Jim Perry, as President and Chief Operating Officer. In 1997, with an estimated revenue of $100 million, Waste Industries went public.[http://www.nasdaq.com/markets/ipos/filing.ashx?filingid=442466 Nasdaq Filing] The company continued to grow that year with an estimated 20 branches, 11 transfer stations and 4 recycling facilities under its belt. In 2000 Waste Industries went through a tech revolution and updated its website. With the website upgrade they also became the first company on the east-coast to incorporate [[e-billing]] for waste pick-up customers. In 2008, the company went private again and experienced a restructuring in its management.[http://news.thomasnet.com/companystory/waste-industries-usa-inc-announces-agreement-to-go-private-for-38-00-per-share-808189 ThomasNet News] Vern Poole, son of original owner Lonnie Poole and long-time company leader, would become Chairman and CEO and would create his personal board.[http://www.bizjournals.com/triangle/stories/2008/12/29/daily24.html Triangle Business Journal] Greg Yorston would later become Chief Operating Office,[http://www.waste360.com/personnel-moves/waste-industries-names-yorston-chief-operating-officer Waste 360 News] Steve Grissiom Chief Financial Officer, and Lisa Inman Senior Vice President and General Counsel. In 2010, [[North Carolina State University]] unveiled a wall display highlighting original Waste Industries founder Lonnie Poole as well as the progress Waste Industries has made over the years as it has grown.[https://poole.ncsu.edu/index-exp.php/news/article/poole-college-installs-wall-display-to-honor-benefactor-lonnie-c.-poole-jr NC State University Board] Poole is a longtime supporter of NC State and provided major investments to create their graduate business degree programs after switching schools to get his MBA due to the lack of a program upon his graduation from NC State with his bachelor’s degree.[http://www.wral.com/news/education/story/8792708/ WRAL News] As of 2014, the company was valued at $570 million with over 1600 employees. On October 10, 2018, the company announced it was going to be sold off to a Canadian Company, [[GFL Environmental]], for an undisclosed amount.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsobserver.com/news/business/article219777470.html?#emlnl=Breaking_Newsletter&id=c25vd2Nvb2w3NzZAZ21haWwuY29t|title=Raleigh’s Waste Industries is being sold to Canadian company|work=newsobserver|access-date=2018-10-10|language=en}} ==Full Circle Project== In 2014, Waste Industries created the Full Circle Project.[http://www.northwestgeorgianews.com/polkfishwrap/news/local/waste-industries-gives-to-local-organizations/article_64224b22-a8c2-11e5-9578-e331948f61f8.html North Georgian News] The Full Circle Project allows employees and customers to give to their favorite non-profit through Waste Industries. To date, Waste Industries has given close to $1 million in non-profit donations. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *[https://wasteindustries.com/ Official Website] *[https://wasteindustries.com/fullcircleproject Full Circle Project] [[Category:Waste management companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in Raleigh, North Carolina]] [[Category:Renewable resource companies established in 1970]] [[Category:Waste industry]] [[Category:1970 establishments in North Carolina]]

Michael Whitehead, President and Founder | products = WhereScape RED, WhereScape 3D | num_employees = 150+ | homepage = [http://www.wherescape.com/ www.wherescape.com] }} '''WhereScape''' is a privately held international [[Data warehouse automation|Data Warehouse Automation]] & [[Big data|Big Data]] [[software]] company with offices in [[Auckland, New Zealand]], [[Portland, Oregon|Portland, Oregon, USA]], [[Reading, United Kingdom]], [[Pune, India]] & [[Singapore]]. == History == WhereScape was founded as a data warehouse consulting company in Auckland, New Zealand{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=3544415 |title=WhereScape sets up for European sales campaign |author=Pamatatau, R. |date=20 Jan 2004 |work= |publisher=The New Zealand Herald |accessdate=}} in 1997 by co-founders Michael Whitehead (President) and Wayne Richmond.{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/christine-nikiel/news/article.cfm?a_id=292&objectid=10476312 |title=What, when, why and WhereScape |author=Nikiel, C. |date=19 Nov 2007 |work= |publisher=The New Zealand Herald |accessdate=}} The company was formerly named Profit Management Systems, but officially renamed to WhereScape in 2001 when expanding business operations into the USA. WhereScape operates out of regional headquarters in Auckland, New Zealand; Portland, Oregon, USA; Reading, United Kingdom; and Singapore. As of 2015 the company has over 720 customers in more than 15 countries and a turnover of around $20 million (NZD).{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=11193903 |title=NZX listing on cards for Wherescape |author=Christopher Adams |date=30 Jan 2014 |work= |publisher=The New Zealand Herald |accessdate=}} Sales channels vary by country but can be either direct sales or through local partners. WhereScape also has partnerships with third-party companies that embed WhereScape software in their solutions.{{cite web|title=WhereScape is helping businesses put data into their decision making.|url=http://www.nzte.govt.nz/en/news-and-media/features/2013-new-zealand-international-business-awards-finalists/anz-best-business-operating-internationally-%E2%80%94-10m-50m/wherescape/|publisher=New Zealand Trade & Enterprise|accessdate=7 November 2013}} == WhereScape Products == WhereScape currently offers two main products: [https://www.wherescape.com/products-services/wherescape-red/ WhereScape RED] and [https://www.wherescape.com/products-services/wherescape-3d/ WhereScape 3D]. As of November 2017, version numbers between the two have been aligned and the current stable version is 8.0.1.0. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{official website|http://www.wherescape.com/}} [[Category:Business intelligence companies]] [[Category:Software companies of New Zealand]] [[Category:Data warehousing products]] [[Category:Extract, transform, load tools]] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]]

[[University of Reading]] |occupation = Businessman |boards = |spouse = Nicola Johnson (divorced) |children = |relatives = [[Amal Clooney]] (niece) }} '''Ziad Takieddine''' ({{lang-ar|زياد تقي الدين}} ; born 14 June 1950) is a [[Lebanese people in France|Lebanese-French]] businessman, described by ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'' as an "arms broker".[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/ziad-takieddine-the-skiresort-owner-with-a-taste-for-the-high-life-8436012.html Ziad Takieddine: The ski-resort owner with a taste for the high life], ''[[The Independent]]'', January 2, 2013John Lichfield, [https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/if-sarko-took-gaddafi-cash-why-oust-him-8439709.html If Sarko took Gaddafi cash, why oust him?], ''The Independent'', January 6, 2013Henry Samuel, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/nicolas-sarkozy/8731692/Briton-in-divorce-with-French-arms-broker-husband-could-hold-key-to-Karachi-affair.html Briton in divorce with French arms broker husband could hold key to 'Karachi affair' ], ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', August 30, 2011[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/03/gaddafi-financed-sarkozy-campaign-2007_n_2403097.html Gaddafi Financed Sarkozy Campaign In 2007, Claims Arms Dealer Ziad Takieddine], ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', 01/03/2013 ==Early life== Ziad Takieddine was born on 14 June 1950 in [[Baakline]], [[Lebanon]] into a [[Druze in Lebanon|Druze]] family.{{cite book|author=Fabrice Arfi|title=Le sens des affaires: Voyage au bout de la corruption|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m8F9BAAAQBAJ&pg=PT53|accessdate=30 October 2015|date=1 October 2014|publisher=Calmann-Lévy|isbn=978-2-7021-5557-8|pages=53–54}} His uncle Saiid Takieddine was Lebanese Ambassador in London, and his father was Ambassador in various countries. He was educated at the [[American University in Beirut]] and the [[University of Reading]] in England. ==Career== In the 1990s, he was the manager of the [[Isola 2000]] [[ski resort]] in [[Isola, Alpes-Maritimes]], France. He later facilitated arms dealing between France and Middle East countries, including [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Pakistan]], [[Syria]] and [[Libya]]. He is under investigation for allegedly using some of those funds to finance the unsuccessful presidential campaign of former French Prime Minister [[Edouard Balladur]]. This has led to the [[Karachi affair]]. He facilitated the release of [[HIV trial in Libya|Bulgarian nurses]] from Libya and organized Libya President Muammar Gaddafi's 2007 visit to France. He has [[Alleged Libyan interference in the 2007 French elections|since accused]] former French President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] of taking 5 million euros from Libyan President [[Muammar Gaddafi]] from 2006 to 2007 Interview of Ziad Takeddine on Mediapart https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WmvSyRGVTew to finance his presidential campaign, a claim echoed by [[Saif al-Islam Gaddafi]]. ==Personal life== His ex-wife, Nicola Johnson, is British-born. She has accused him of [[tax evasion]] in France. Takieddine owns Warwick House in London's Holland Park district via a company in the [[tax haven]] of the [[British Virgin Islands]].{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Neighbours from hell|work=[[Private Eye (magazine)|Private Eye]]|issue=1404|date=30 October 2015|page=37|subscription=|via=}} In 2013 Takieddine was denied entry to the United Kingdom following an "allegation of fraud" and was forced by British police to return to France.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/arms-deals-fixer-ziad-takieddine-refused-entry-and-returned-to-france-9032101.html|title=Arms deals fixer Ziad Takieddine refused entry and returned to France|date=31 December 2013|work=The Independent|accessdate=11 November 2015}} Takieddine is an uncle of [[Amal Clooney|Amal Alamuddin]], who is married to the actor [[George Clooney]].{{cite web|url=https://www.metro.news/amal-clooneys-uncle-why-i-blew-the-whistle-over-sarkozy-bung/985364/|title=Amal Clooney’s uncle: Why I blew the whistle over Sarkozy ‘bung’|author=|date=|website=metro.news|accessdate=22 March 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Takieddine, Ziad}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:French people of Lebanese descent]] [[Category:Druze people of Lebanese nationality]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:Lebanese businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People named in the Panama Papers]]

'''ʻUliti Uata''' (born 24 August 1936<ref name="gov">[http://www.pmo.gov.to/appointments/new-ministers-/2084-hon-uliti-uata-appointed-as-minister-for-health "Hon. 'Uliti Uata appointed as Minister for Health"], Tongan government portal, 27 January 2011</ref>) is a [[Tonga]]n politician. He is a member of the [[Human Rights and Democracy Movement]] and the [[Democratic Party of the Friendly Islands]].<ref>[http://www.taimionline.com/articles/1581 "MP ‘Uliti Uata tipped as new Health Minister"], Taimi Media Network, January 22, 2010</ref>
==Biography== He was initially a businessman, running several businesses including "inter-islands ferries, general store, tourism, and others", until he entered politics and "divested himself" of his businesses so as to focus on his political career and on his family (he has ten children).<ref name="gov" />
Uata was first elected to the [[Legislative Assembly of Tonga]] in 1975, and served as a People's Representative until 1980. After a break from politics, he contested the [[Tongan general election, 1993|1993 election]] and won the seat of [[Ha'apai]]. He has been re-elected in every subsequent election.<ref>[http://www.parliament.gov.to/about-parliament/members/people/207-uliti-uata.html Biography] on the website of the Tongan Parliament</ref>
In 2007 Uata was one of several pro-democracy MPs charged with [[sedition]] over speeches given before the [[2006 Nuku'alofa riots]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=32703 |title=Decision next week in Tonga on trial of sedition suspects |publisher=Radio New Zealand International |date=2007-06-02 |accessdate=2010-03-02}}</ref> The charges were dismissed in September 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=49080 |title=Five acquitted on charges of seditious conspiracy in Tonga |publisher=Radio new Zealand International |date=2009-09-13 |accessdate=2010-03-01}}</ref>
Uata was re-elected for an eighth term in the [[Tongan general election, 2010|2010 election]], for the new single-seat constituency of [[Haʻapai 13]], and nominated to the post of Minister of Health on 25 January 2011, following [[ʻAkilisi Pohiva]]'s resignation from that position.<ref>[http://www.matangitonga.to/article/tonganews/government/20110126_tonga_uliti.shtml "New Minister of Health"], Matangi Tonga, 26 Jan 2011</ref> In late June 2012, Uata -along with two other ministers- resigned from the Cabinet, so as to support a [[motion of no confidence]] tabled by his party (DPFI) against the government.<ref>[http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=69116 "Three Cabinet Ministers in Tonga resign ahead of confidence motion"], Radio New Zealand International, 25 June 2012</ref> He was succeeded as Minister for Health by [[Lord Tonga Tuʻiʻafitu|Lord Tuʻiʻafitu]].<ref>[http://matangitonga.to/2012/07/09/pms-new-cabinet-short-ministers "PM's new Cabinet short of ministers"], ''Matangi Tonga'', 9 July 2012</ref>
